title: Tories pledge to obey courts on woman's state pension age as ministers face fury
text:

Tory ministers tonight pledged they will obey any future court ruling on state pension age rises for 3.8million women.

The vow came as campaigners mull launching a Court of Appeal fight after their original bid to find the rises unlawful failed in the High Court.

Last week's ruling came after years of battles for around 3.8million women born in the 1950s, who are having their state pension age hiked so it reaches 66 by 2020.

Ministers say the change is to make women's retirement age equal to men's - and would cost £181bn to fully reverse.

Two women took legal action saying the rises were unlawful age and sex discrimination and came with too little notice. But campaigners shouted "shame on you!" as their legal fight was "dismissed on all grounds".

Today Tory pensions minister Guy Opperman confirmed: "This government will abide by court decisions and follow the law.

(Image: PA)

"And if there are any changes to the two independent High Court judges who heard the case and made the decision, then clearly the government will obey that."

But women would face a long battle in the Court of Appeal before they would win any new help.

And today Tory ministers were slammed from all sides in the Commons for not doing more to help the women sooner.

Tory MP Tim Loughton warned "many are still struggling" and urged ministers to consider new transitional arrangements.

Tory MP Julian Lewis also demanded "alternative schemes" to "mitigate the problems that have resulted".

218 MPs have backed a motion demanding a "temporary special measure" in law to provide "restitution" to 3.8million women hit.

(Image: PA)

Labour's Shadow Pensions Minister Jack Dromey demanded more help for the women affected.

He said: "3.8 million women born in the 1950s, who built Britain, face hardship as the consequence of pension changes by this Government and argued before the court - a cavalier disregard - they were told they had no right to be consulted in terms of the change of retirement age.

" Labour has already committed to some preliminary measures, early retirement, pension credit and we will now consult with the women concerned about how much further we can go to bring justice to them."

He said: "Thus far, the Government has committed to nothing.

"The Prime Minister said however during the Conservative leadership contest, and I quote, he is committed to doing everything he can to bring justice to the 1950s women.

"Can the minister update the House on progress or will this be just another cynical broken promise on the part of the Prime Minister?"

But there were angry objections from Labour MPs as Mr Opperman suggested Mr Dromey should consult his own wife - Harriet Harman, a former minister in the Labour government.

A hike to women's state pension age from 60 to 65, over 10 years starting in 2010, was first proposed in the 1995 Pensions Act.

But that was accelerated by the 2011 Pensions Act, which laid out plans to hike the age to 65 in November 2018 - followed by 66 in October 2020.

Facing an outcry, ministers agreed a £1.1bn concession in the final stages of the Act, supposedly to limit any one person's pension age rise to 18 months.

Mr Opperman said: "Well clearly these matters are the matter of a court case which may be the subject of appeal.

"But with real great respect to (him) who is to his discredit a friend of mine, the honest truth is that he should be consulting with a 1950s-born woman who was secretary of state for the department (for) work and pensions, who is the MP for Camberwell and Peckham, who is also his wife, who was also responsible for the continuation of the self same policy that he now objects to.

"It is the Labour Party for 13 years who did the perfectly proper thing of taking due account of equality and the rises in life expectancy, and it is something that they should stick to having made the decisions for 13 years."
description: Ministers gave faint hope to women who are considering a Court of Appeal fight - but were slammed by all sides for not doing more to help them now
